issues.description: Conflicting instructions about the SealSaloon.stock field: the problem text instructs students to make the stock a final Stock and to initialize it in the constructor (instance initialization), but it also states that the stock attribute must be static (shared across instances). In Java a static final field cannot be assigned in an instance constructor (static finals must be initialized at declaration or in a static initializer). This makes the combination of requirements impossible to satisfy and will confuse students about how to declare and initialize the field.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the specification consistent: either (A) require an instance (non-static) final Stock initialized in the instance constructor, or (B) require a static final Stock and instruct students to initialize it at declaration or in a static initializer. Update the problem text to explicitly state the chosen option and show the correct initialization approach (e.g., "private static final Stock stock = new Stock();" or "private final Stock stock; this.stock = new Stock();" in the constructor). This removes the impossible requirement of assigning a static final field inside an instance constructor.

issues.description: Method name/signature mismatch between the problem statement and the solution: the problem (UML and text) specifies a static method acceptSupplyDelivery(String, int, int) but the solution implements a static method named receiveDelivery(String, int, int). This discrepancy will confuse students about the required API and will break any tests or instructions expecting acceptSupplyDelivery.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the method name in all artifacts. Either rename the solution method receiveDelivery to acceptSupplyDelivery (keeping the same parameters and static modifier), or update the problem statement/UML to require receiveDelivery instead of acceptSupplyDelivery. Prefer changing the solution to acceptSupplyDelivery to match the problem statement and tests, and ensure the template (when providing method signatures or documentation) uses the same name.

issues.description: The problem statement (and the commented example in Main) refer to a static method named 'acceptSupplyDelivery(String, int, int)' on SealSaloon, but the solution implementation provides a static method named 'receiveDelivery(String, int, int)'. This naming mismatch means students reading the task and the example code expect acceptSupplyDelivery to exist, while the reference solution implements the same functionality under a different identifier. This creates confusion mapping the requirement to the implementation and will cause compile/runtime mismatch if students copy the example call or expect the specific method name from the problem.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the method name across artifacts. Rename the solution method 'receiveDelivery' to 'acceptSupplyDelivery' with the same signature (static void acceptSupplyDelivery(String name, int price, int quantity)), or add a static wrapper 'acceptSupplyDelivery' that delegates to 'receiveDelivery'. Also ensure example calls in Main use the same identifier.
